contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Make ready the way of the Lord ... make his paths straight

contextId.information: Both of these phrases mean basically the same thing. They emphasize that a person cannot love and be devoted both to God and money at the same time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: for either he will hate the one and love the other, or else he will be devoted to one and despise the other

contextId.information: Matthew is quoting the prophet Isaiah. These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that he healed all of our diseases. AT: "healed those who were sick and made them well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: took our sickness and bore our diseases

contextId.information: Both of these statements mean the same thing. Jesus is emphasizing that God will make all things known. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will reveal the things that people hide" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: there is nothing concealed that will not be revealed, and nothing hidden that will not be known

contextId.information: Both of these statements mean the same thing. Jesus is emphasizing that the disciples should tell everyone what he tells the disciples in private. AT: "Tell people in the daylight what I tell you in the darkness, and proclaim upon the housetops what you hear softly in your ear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: What I tell you in the darkness, say in the daylight, and what you hear softly in your ear, proclaim upon the housetops

contextId.information: Both of these phrases mean the same thing. Jesus is emphasizing that it is easier to obey him than it is the Jewish law. AT: "For what I place on you, you will be able to carry because it is light" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: For my yoke is easy and my burden is light

contextId.information: Jesus uses this parallelism to tell and emphasize to the disciples that the crowd refuses to understand God's truth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Though they are seeing, they do not see; and though they are hearing, they do not hear, or understand.

contextId.information: Both of these statements mean the same thing. Jesus is emphasizing that they have pleased God because they have believed what Jesus has said and done. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: But blessed are your eyes, for they see; and your ears, for they hear

contextId.information: Both sentences mean the same thing. They are combined to emphasize that Jesus taught the crowds only with parables. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: All these things Jesus said to the crowds in parables; and he said nothing to them without a parable

contextId.information: All three of these phrases mean basically the same thing. They mean a person must love God with all of their inner being and with complete devotion. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: with all your heart, with all your soul, and with all your mind

contextId.information: These two statements mean the same thing. They refer to a farmer who gathers crops that do not belong to him. The servant uses this metaphor to accuse the master of being a ruthless businessman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You reap where you did not sow, and you harvest where you did not scatter

contextId.information: These two statements mean the same thing. They refer to a farmer who gathers crops that do not belong to him. The servant uses this metaphor to accuse the master of being a ruthless businessman. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:25:24|25:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I reap where I have not sowed and harvest where I have not scattered
